questions.neutral: You made it in one piece?

hobby.message: Still chasing ghosts with analog photography?
Still folding origami to stay grounded?
Political literature still your guilty pleasure?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Still in one piece. Just out walking, kept it routine.
Had my camera with me—analog, nothing fancy. Just old habits.
Didn’t get much today, lots of eyes everywhere.
People seem restless. Hard to find a good shot.
Guess that’s what happens when everything’s up in the air.
Yeah, made it. Took the long route—just in case.
Was out with my 35mm camera, trying to get some street shots.
Film’s rare to come by these days, and the system hiccups didn’t help.
Not easy freezing moments with all the system lags after Halden.
Feels like even the film gets nervous when the city does.
Survived the walk. Had my analog camera with me—still not ready to trade it for digital.
I was out shooting for a while. Street scenes, faces—real stuff you can’t fake.
The city’s felt off since Halden’s announcement, you know? Makes every snapshot count.
Film’s finicky. Missed a whole roll because one of the drop boxes jammed from a system fault.
But that’s half the fun—catching things when the city drops its mask.
Barely, but that’s part of the game. Took my Nikon out—35mm, actual film. Some people think I’m crazy for sticking with it.
Been chasing those raw, unfiltered street moments all evening. The city’s jumpy since the BCI started glitching after Halden’s death.
My favorite drop spot for film refused to open—tech acting up everywhere. Had to improvise, find a hand who would help.
Truth is, with everything so watched and mediated, real moments are rare. Film feels like the only honest witness left.
You see all this stuff from behind the bar. But through a lens, you catch what the system misses.
One piece, just barely. Honestly, I risked more for a good shot than for my reports tonight.
I brought my analog camera—and not just for nostalgia. My father was BCI when I was a kid. He always said, 'The system leaves footprints, but so do we.' That’s why I use film. It’s harder to erase.

Tonight the city was different—crowds tense, surveillance drones skating lower than usual. Even Bar 101’s drop box glitched out after Halden. Had to call in a favor for something that should’ve been simple.

Most folks think I shoot for state media, but my real work is these off-the-record rolls. System’s breaking cover, so people reveal themselves—in a glance, a hesitation. Makes every shutter click heavier.

Used to think you could just tell the truth. Now, you have to sneak up and steal it. That’s why I’m out there, with film—no edits, no algorithm to filter what you see. Just me, the city, and what’s left when the network fails.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Analog photography. Good to have something steady.
Film just… works. Most days.
Last week the scanners at the tram glitched—people were tense.
Hard to get candid shots now, everyone notices.
System errors after Halden died slowed everything down.
I stick to the edges. Less attention that way.
Analog photography—keeps me grounded.
It’s getting trickier lately, with the city in fallback mode.
Last week, system glitches locked up half my normal drop spots.
Everyone’s more alert since Halden’s death. Makes street shots risky.
Had to wait out a drone patrol before developing film.
Not as comfortable as it used to be.
Analog photography—the quiet rebellion, as you said.
I like framing real moments, no filters, nothing staged.
Since Halden's death, the BCI’s been glitchy—access to drop boxes is unreliable.
Caught a scene at the tram line last week: woman’s travel card failed, nobody spoke.
The city feels different. Faces closed off, routines break.
Even just storing a roll got complicated with all the system delays.
Analog photography—it’s become my way to catch what the feeds miss.
Since everything went sideways after Halden died, people move strangely—like they’re expecting something.
Took a shot of a market line—pure tension in their eyes, all from a BCI malfunction.
Had to bribe a maintenance guy just to access a darkroom last night; fallback mode was locking community spaces.
Those unscripted seconds tell more truth than any state report I file.
I started saving extra contact sheets, in case something goes missing.
Analog photography—the last thing that feels real, honestly.
Dad used to run BCI compliance; he never got why film matters, but I think he'd get it now, given the chaos since Halden’s death.
Every street shot is a gamble—drones hovering low, access points failing. The city’s got this electric nervousness, like it’s off-script for once.
Last Friday my entire backup stash nearly got locked out because Halden’s override credentials were missing. I nearly lost a week’s work to a system prompt.
Even with all that, I'm obsessed—these moments, before the system adapts, are the rawest I’ve ever captured.
I don’t upload much through official channels. Encryption, hard copies, I trust my own hands more than any terminal these days.
